reviewText:
Hahaha, get it? It's like Oregon Trail, but...

No, it really is Oregon Trail with zombies. But instead of being a one-note joke, Organ Trail actually improves on the original formula in significant ways. If you somehow never encountered an Apple IIe in school, the basic idea of ______ Trail games is that you have a party of 4 or so travelers on their way to a distant destination. Random things happen on the way, sometimes you get a choice to make, other times not. Settlements give you the chance to shop, barter, or scavenge for supplies. Organ Trail sets this up as you and your 4 pals escaping D.C. in a beat-up station wagon, carrying as much food, ammo, car parts, and fuel as you can. In addition to the random horrible things that happen, you'll also encounter minigames like dodging zombie deer and motorcycle gangs on the highway, or making a clutch shot to save a friend from a kidnapper. These interactive events really help break up the monotony of watching your beater roll down the highway while bad things happen to you all.

Settlements are where the game really shines, because there are a wealth of options for managing your journey. In terms of supplies alone, you can buy and sell for cash, wait for trade offers on your goods, scavenge by playing a little top-down action minigame, and do side missions (also minigames) to get paid in goods. There are additional options for managing the health of your team, for maintaining and upgrading your ride, and even learning new special skills for your player character that help in minigames. Learning how much you need of what resources and what upgrades you should spring for can take time, so be prepared to either lose a few times or start on Easy. The first time I picked this game up I got rather frustrated because my car broke down and I got trapped in a settlement with no way to repair it. But after a few more rounds I learned the power of scavenging and practiced my minigaming and now everything runs smooth... on Normal, anyway.

It's a pretty deep game for a literal Oregon Trail clone, and the zombie aspect fits the style well without being tired. There are some cute pop culture references that are clever enough not to annoy, and plenty of replay value. As long as the ultra low-res graphics and learning curve don't put you off, this is a grand little coffee break game.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GQlzxgBEPdA

The Men Who Wear Many Hats originally created Organ Trail as a flash game and after some fund raising they were able to release an expanded version of their original title on mobile devices and now PC. Organ Trail takes it's primary inspiration from the original Apple II iteration of The Oregon Trail and opens with your character encountering Clement, a fellow survivor who kick-starts your odyssey across a post apocalyptic United States. Much like the game it parodies, Organ Trail is about balance. You will need to ensure that your party is fed, rested and your car in tip top mechanical condition. With every mile that ticks by your parties health degrades as well as your trusty station wagon. Injury and disease are common occurrences on the road as evidenced by the many tombstones that can be encountered on your journey. These tombstones are not only reminders of the peril that face your party but also opportunities for upgrades and supplies. Party members can be bitten on your voyage and may require a euthanizing rifle blast to the head. Of course, if you are a misanthropic sociopath you could always off your healthy party members and not have to worry about keeping them fed and healthy. Dotting the trail to safety are landmarks and cities that allow your party to trade, buy and sell items, upgrade your car and purchase perks for your character. You can also take on jobs to earn some cash or supplies and chat the locals up for information.

Scavenging is often the easiest way to stay supplied on your journey. By opting to scavenge an open field pops up with random items spawning. Little green zombies home in on your character as you attempt to scoop up scrap for car repairs, food for nourishment, and cash for additional supplies. It's possible to defend yourself from the zombie onslaught while scavenging with a rifle. You must click and pull your mouse back which brings up a line of site on the screen which you can then spin while in a fixed position to dial your site in on the revolting rotting flesh heaps that converge on your position. Releasing fires and these controls take a bit of time to acclimate yourself to. A couple of seconds to reload between each round ensures a bit of tension as you scramble for goodies. Bosses are also randomly encountered on these scavenging excursions. They are more robust creatures that put up a bit more of a fight than your average walking corpse.

The jobs that are on offer use variations of these mechanics. Some require you to defend a position by taking cover and killing zombies before they reach your position, some have you locating an item in a scrolling field while zombies swarm and the last variant has you trading gun shots with others humans in fortified positions. These mini games can feel repetitive after a while since your character doesn't receive new weapons and enemy types are limited. The randomness of these events will keep you coming back however. Also, random encounters with biker gangs and hordes of zombie deer mix things up while in your station wagon. Random interactions with other travelers on the road also spice up the core game and offer a little bit of narrative. Prompts will appear that ask if you feel inclined to investigate something on the road. Doing so kicks off an old school adventure sequence that often results in a reward of some sort. This touch adds quite a bit of re-playability to Organ Trail. While the randomness of Organ Trail ensures a new experience every time it can  also lead to frustration. It's not uncommon for tragic events to occur in quick succession and take out a party member or even your party leader. It can be upsetting, perhaps off putting for some, when a well supplied and positioned expedition fails because of a bout with dysentery and broken ribs...

Ultimately Organ Trail: Director's cut is one of the best games to emerge from the zombie zeitgeist that has gripped popular culture over the past half decade.

reviewText:
The walking dead simulator

Organ trail is unique 2D Rogue-like management game with zombies.

The gameplay is this game's main highlight. Before you start your game, you get to name your character as well as your group members. It is generally advised that you name group members based on people you love/hate (famous people etc) as it will make the experience more interesting as you watch how long they last. After that you get to choose the types of items you will carry along with you like feul, food, money etc. You begin your journey in your station wagon traveling to the next city. Along your travel you may face some random encounters which may affect the game e.g. losing items, more vehicle damage, random stop, members getting sick etc. As you travel you will also consume fuel. Should you run out of feul you can either scavange some or spend time waiting for someone to come along and trade you some. Scavenging involves collecting resources while fending off zombies with your gun. Aiming with you gun is terrible (which isn't surprising because this is basically an android port) as it involves clicking and draging to where you want to shoot and then missing most of the time (It takes a while to get used to basically). When you reach towns you can talk to survivors, take side quests which involves fending against zombies or bandits (which gives you resources as rewards), buy/sell supplies (fuel, food, ammo), heal the group as well as repairing and upgrading your station wagon. Like feul food is also depleted as you travel. You have the option of rationalising the consumption of food. Should it be depleted you and your other survivors will gradually lose health until they die. You also have an option to kill any of you party members at anytime, should you no longer require their company. You basically move from city to city surviving the zombie apocalypse as much as you can until you reach the sanctuary. Should you die, the game immeditaely ends and you are taken back to the main menu to begin a fresh run again if you wish. The game is quite challenging and addicitve so you will play this game a several times.

The music adds to desloate atmosphere. Whether your in a town, traveling or hunting you get to experience a spooky and lonely soundtrack which helps to instill the feeling of trying to survive a zombie apocalypse. The weapon sounds aren't that great.

There isn't much story to the game. Basically the intro starts you off with meeting some survivors. You formulate a plan to get to the sanctuary (city free of zombies) and begin your journey together in the station wagon.

The graphics aren't that great. They do an OK job at presenting a dark atmosphere, but they lack detail.

If you want a resource management rogue-like game with zombies and don't min wonky shooting controls, this game will appease your interests.

reviewText:
Instead of going to Oregon to stake a claim on America's future, you decide the fate of a group of survivors looking for a safe place to live in a post-apocalyptic world overridden by zombies.  You travel from Washington DC, that's about to be nuked, all the way to a safe haven in, you guessed it, Oregon.  The game is faithful in every way it can be to the Oregon Trail, except where it could be made more thematically appropriate to a zombie apocalypse, with multiple additions to improve the simulation and theming.  Seriously, name a feature from Oregon Trail and it's there.  Dysentary?  Check.  Bad water?  Check.  Tombstones?  Check.  You get the picture.

Oregon Trail's 'hunting' minigame, being the best part of the original, has become a bit more central to the experience with Scavenging and Jobs using it, with a few others including Defense, Surrounded and Bandit Raid events using the same shooting mechanics.
When Scavenging, you no longer shoot a 2000 pound buffalo to carry back 100 pounds of meat.  Instead you rummage around a wilderness, collecting any supplies that pop up (including food, cash and scrap that you can use to repair your car), while avoiding and shooting zombies that swarm in on you.  Learning to control the flow of these zombies to reduce the amount of ammo I have to spend was a fun mechanic to master (no doubt aided by my recent experience with Gauntlet), and I must say, is probably the best way to ensure your victory at the game.

In a funny way, Organ Trail is one of the most complete zombie apocalypse simulations I've played, and if you like the genre, you really should play it just because it's a fun game.  If that's not enough to attract you, maybe the novelty of recreating the Oregon Trail experience on a modern platform with a modern genre is enough.  I would happily recommend Organ Trail even at the premium price of five bucks.

reviewText:
This is a parody of the old classic Oregon Trail, but with a zombie twist to it. The real selling point seems to be that parody. You start out as a party of 5 and work your way from Washington DC headed west. It is a supply and demand sort of game where when you start, you buy your supplies, then at times you'll run low whether it is med kits, fuel, batteries, food or ammo. How do you get more? You stop and trade, scavenge or doing odd jobs.

Organ Trail is broken up into cities that have places to buy and sell things. They'll also have either combat training or auto repair shops where you can buy mufflers, batteries, tires or upgrades. You can also fix your car at the shops. If you don't have the cash to repair your car, you can always use scrap, but using X amount of scrap only gets you X percentage the repair will be successful. Like 2 scrap will be 20% successful.

If you can't make it to a city, you can stop at any time to repair your car, scavenge, rest for health regeneration, kill infected party members and use med kits. I seemed to find traders more frequently when I stopped outside of a city. When you scavenge, make sure to pay attention to what the game tells you the zombie activity is. More zombies, more problems. The jobs also tell you the risk factor, anywhere from normal to suicide. Just make sure the reward is worth the risk and play it safe.

The game is full of mini games. Scavenge has you slowly running around a screen dodging zombies, collecting random things. Sometimes the game will bust out a boss to chase you that is far more difficult to avoid than the zombies. When scavenging, you don't even need to shoot, so much as run and avoid. There are defense mini games that require you to stay put and shoot either zombies or bandits. The shooting feels very imprecise and has you clicking on a zombie with your mouse and dragging it back to your character to aim, then releasing the mouse button to fire. There are a lot of misses even with what looks like a perfectly aimed shot.

There is a mini game where your station wagon gets chased by a biker gang and you need to run them off the road and there is even a mini game where you dodge reindeer chasing after your station wagon. After you complete Organ Trail, it will unlock a Clemons mini game that has you driving a station wagon left going up triangle hills, jumping off and ramming zombies in a side scroller.

When you are on the road, random events happen, such as your characters breaking bones, getting diseases, being mugged, losing items, finding graves, wading through zombies, helping people, looting bodies, injuring your entire party and so much more. Its all text for the most part.

After you complete the game, it unlocks an endless mode. The interesting part of endless mode are the modifiers, such as your party can start out infected or they are deep sleepers and recover twice as fast. The sad thing is endless mode is really endless, and I just don't like the thought of being able to play Organ Trail forever.

Even with all of the random events that make every playthrough different, it felt like a chore having to scavenge so much. It was as if the scavenging was the bulk of my play throughs. I didn't find it fun. The random events are really just that, random and rarely benefit you, which is why its more of a supply and demand game. Everything is designed to drain you, but then you need to compensate for it. Please just skip this game, it looks cool, it sounds cool, but there aren't moments of 'yay I did it!' so much as moments of 'how would hitting a bump in the road lose 2 med kits?' Oh well.

Admittedly part of my disappointment might be because the version of Oregon Trail I grew up with was Oregon Trail II, which had some pretty campy FMV stuff in it but had more stuff to do overall and felt like a fuller game. They just took him. Grabbed him from the back seat of the car and took him. Sure, he was annoying at times. He lost more cash than he ever earned, and somehow got himself shot by a stray bullet, but Sketch was one of us y'know? Us survivors have to stick together.

So I picked up my rifle and stepped out of the car. I didn't have much choice. I wasn't going to leave him behind. Ottah hadn't looked good for some time since the first Z he saw took a chunk of him. Sleepy got bitten soon after. As for Rabid, I'm pretty sure she was high the whole time. She never got ill, never caused a problem. I forgot she was there most of the time.

So, there I was. It was an old fashioned stand-off. The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ was hiding behind Sketchy, holding a pistol to his head. I didn't need to think. I just shot. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=139325029
From that moment on, there was no turning back. Anyone who stood between my guys and Safe Haven, dead or alive, I took them out.

It was tough, but we made it. All of us made it. Hopefully Ottah and Sleepy will be able to live with the bites. As for me, there are more survivors out there and someone needs to help them ...


That was the story of my first adventure in Organ Trail. I foolishly played on Easy, which I wont be doing again, as once I learned my way around the game it wasn't very challenging. I guess I'm too used to recent roguelikes murdering me on my first turn! (I'm looking at you FTL)

I always get an extra kick out of games where I can name multiple members of a party. Naming the characters after my buddies helped me grow attached to them. Or hate them for constantly being ill (Ottah!) or a pain in the ♥♥♥♥ (Sketch!). The shooting took a little to get used to, but it was okay once I got the hang of it.

As for replayability, Endless Mode offers up unique starting scenarios and there are a fair few of them. I'll be making a start on those real soon!

The sound style matches the graphics, but I'll happily play this on mute and listen to my own music. It's not a problem with the style of the music, I just find it to be quite bad. Also, I'm sure I heard a dodgy distorted version of the 'Happy Birthday' tune at some point.

The most important thing I have to say about Organ Trail, is that I want to play more. As soon as I finished the game, I wanted to play again. That's the sign of good gameplay. Organ Trail doesn't have fancy graphics to fall back on. All it's can offer is its solid gameplay. If you're a fan of survival games, and don't mind the design this is something that you should pick up.

Bottom Line: Organ Trail is fun and leaves you wanting more.

reviewText:
TLDR – This is a remake of the Apple IIe classic Oregon Trail that you may remember (if you’re old like me) from a couple decades ago. It’s significantly longer and more difficult though, and has the added threat of zombies.

There’s not much story to be found in Organ Trail, just you and a group of friends driving west across the United States in a station wagon trying to reach Safe Haven on the west coast. On the way you’re set upon by random occurrences (almost all of them bad) and have to stay alive through resource management and generous use of your rifle.

Gameplay wise, your travel path is fixed, and while you can increase/decrease your rate of travel (it affects the rate at which your car breaks down) you will always have the same distance to travel to reach the end of the game (no shortcuts). Just like in the old Oregon Trail game, probably the only part of the game you have direct control over is the “scavenging” missions where you walk around a small area looking for food. In Oregon Trail, you shot at animals like deer and rabbits to collect food, but in Organ Trail you collect randomly appearing goodies while shooting at the zombies chasing you. Pretty much all the old events that plagued you in Oregon Trail are back (dysentery, random weather, losing inventory items) but now you and your group can be infected by zombies (no cure for a zombie bite).

Pros:
+Nostalgia for an old classic game
+People who enjoy “rogue-like” games may appreciate the randomness of Organ Trail

Cons:
-The game is very hard, even on easy mode because of all the randomly occurring problems. There really isn’t any “skill” involved with beating the game. It mostly depends on how lucky you are.
-If you’re into high end graphics, you’re looking in the wrong place. This game is practically 8-bit.

I played Organ Trail because my video card died and I couldn’t run anything with modern graphics. It’s a decent way to spend a few hours, but surely there are better games that you’d rather be playing after the nostalgia factor wears off.

reviewText:
Depressing, but not quite as depressing as FTL.

This is actually a far better game than Oregon Trail, or most zombie games for that matter, because the bad luck can be remedied with good performance in the arcade sequences. There are several, and they aren't afterthoughts. They're actually fun minigames. Unlike the old action interludes they parody, they're designed to frighten and challenge while still giving you a fair shake at success. Despite its appearance, this is a new videogame first and a retro homage last. Its underlying design is sophisticated and graceful.

Much has been said about the awkward aiming controls, but they are like some ancient forgotten system unearthed by gaming archaeologists. I got used to them quickly, without ever becoming too comfortable. They add a manageable awkwardness to the combat encounters that I enjoyed.

My one objection was the jarring experience of losing outright when my main character died, something I did not expect after finding myself in a groove of what seemed like a classic party adventure. This game feels more like a successor to Might & Magic, Starflight, and indeed FTL than it feels like like a one-joke riff on a piece of pop nostalgia, and I was a little bummed to just have the story end with four of my party still alive. Then again, there's something to be said for never finding out what happened to those guys. It's a little haunting, a bit more of what we fear about death than usually makes it into a game.

Two bonus stars for an appropriate and pretty chiptune soundtrack, good production values, modern resolution options, and for somehow being much easier on the eyes than screenshots might lead you to believe.

reviewText:
An excellent game limited by it's lack of variation and choices.

Replayability is very large but long-play-at-once is harmed by lack of variation and repetitiveness. Very fun to try another game at harder difficulties, but if it drags on for too long you eventually become exhausted of the lack of surprises and it's very hard to keep interest. This happened in my first run. Scavenging consists of picking randomly appearing items on a limited map as zombies randomly spawn and get close to you, for 40 seconds. Sometimes you'll need to scavenge many times in a row. Yeah.

Music is one of the best i've seen around, a frankenstein composed of chiptune music mixed with real instruments, super capable of conveying the emotions of having to put down your now-8-bit best friend after realizing you weren't going to have enough food to make it to safe haven at this pace.

Could have had a lot of variation item wise, and would have been nice to have more things to look at, talking to strangers just consists of a text screen, and you can do it anywhere, even when not in towns. It made you question the solidity of the plot; just how many people are going on the roads at once if you can talk to anybody at anytime? Why is it dangerous then?

Once you learn the mechanics it's very, very hard to die. Resting can get over any disease, broken leg, or bullet wound. There's no apparent benefit from keeping your friends  alive other than having extra support at finales and the score multiplier. They won't complain about your choices, you'll never be kicked off being a leader or care too much if someone gets bitten, after all, they won't die if they get bitten unless their health goes really low. Which is prevented with resting a few hours per town. Yeah.

Otherwise, the game is really great and the first run you'll be covering your face hoping the scrap you managed to collect before you starved is able to fix your car so you can get to the next town and hopefully buy food. Real tense moments where your hands are tied and you must project into the future to know what to do, maybe Bobby doesn't deserve coming with you guys if he ruined food by sitting on it or throwing your only muffler at a zombie. Or maybe you could sell Karen to cannibals for 250 dollars. Hm. Or you are very wounded but Joe needs the medkit because he's suffering from radiation poisoning and his skin is ♥♥♥♥ing falling off.

Gameplay 7/10
Music 10/10
Graphics 6.5/10 (this is because of the lack of variety, instead of being very low detail, it's supposed to be like that dummy)

Overall 8/10

It's worth the full price, it's great to pass the time. Although, a friend gifted it to me.

reviewText: As a person who's basically addicted to this game with over 100 hours of breaking limbs, getting Dysentry, and playing both Endless and beating the Campaign over. I can clearly say that I love this game. Naming your rag-tag group of survivors after friends, and soon letting yourself be more immersed in the atmosphere and looking past the retro pixel graphics, you got yourself a zombie survival game. It's really a huge part of my own personal fun of how I can imagine and experience my friends or certain people coming along to my ride, going through starvation, infection, bandits, zombies, and the like. With the chores of taking care of supplies, you can go at the game with your own pace, either it be conservative, going at a slow pace while trying to save as much food by starving your party, or much more aggressive/safe where you go as fast as possible, pushing your car to limits, as you give a huge buffet for all your party members to keep them healthy. There are two main modes to the game. There's the campaign mode;moving from Washington D.C all the way to the west coast to your final destination: Safe Haven. Then there's Endless mode, with you going as far as possible in the fastest pace for more points, trying to keep yourself, and (depending on your playstyle.) keeping your party alive. This is honestly a great simple game, with an amazing soundtrack along with lots of events occuring along with RNGesus to dicate a slow-death, or a plentiful gold mine of food, medkits, and other supplies. With the complete edition DLC, all your fun with the game only doubles, now adding extras! Such as even MORE RNGesus to give you more ways to death, a lot more choices in what you do. An amazing parody/redesign to the original Oregon Trail. Every dollar was worth it.

reviewText:
I first heard about Organ Trail from a youtuber who played the free flashgame version of this game a couple of months back.
Later i heard about it from another youtuber who played the version on steam and i really enjoyed how the game looked, so i bought it.

So far i don't regret it. The goal of the game is to make it from the east coast of the usa to the west coast. If you take into cosideration that a zombie apocalypse is taking place while you are trying to achieve that, it certainly doesn't make things any easier.
The gameplay is simple but really intense: You and 4 other survivors (which you can name however you like) travel in a car from landmark to landmark. On the way from one landmark to another there are various things that can happen: You get robbed by thieves who steal your fuel, someone gets bitten by a zombie, a horde of deers appears behind you and you have to dodge them, someone gets sick, etc. etc.
On the landmarks you get the chance to trade with other survivors for food, fuel, medkits, etc. You get to scavenge for supplies, repair your car or get perks from traders.
All in all the gameplay is pretty simple, but awfully intense. The fact that you never know what happens on the road and the feeling you get when you are close to the safe haven but you don't know if you can make it because you are low on fuel or food is really nervewrecking and well done.

Oh and the graphics and sound are phenomenal. 8-bit awesomeness from top to bottom.

I'd recommend this game. The replayabilty is also pretty high, since every run is different and there is an endless mode to sum it all up. It's definitely worth 5 bucks. And if you are not sure, try out the free flashgame on the interwebs.

reviewText:
This one took me by surprise. Organ Trail is a old school adventure game where you travel by car, along with 4 of your friends, to a safe place where you're totally free of zombie attacks and other dangers.

The art style is retro, so there are a lot of crude pixels and minimal sounds. I guess that also makes the gameplay retro, because it certainly isn't all that easy.

There are so many things you have to take into consideration. Do you have enough spare tires, batteries and gas for your car, or enough food and medkits for your crew ? Are you prepared to trade stuff in order to get some of these things ? Do you even have stuff to trade ? If not, you have to scavenge for items. But is it safe from zombies or is the place packed ? And do you spend your money on buying upgrades for your car, or do you spend it on buying just the necessary ?
There are a few boss fights, too, and quite a couple of random events, like, what are you going to do when a friend is being held hostage (shoot the guy in the face of course !) ? These random factors make this a great and fun game.

The aiming, however (when you're scavenging or doing jobs), takes some getting used to. It becomes somewhat natural after a while, but doesn't feel quite right. I guess the developer chose this control scheme to keep the game more tense. If that's the case; they have succeeded. Congratulations developer !

If you're still on the fence about buying this: I can highly recommended it.

[Rating: 81/100]

Right away I’m brought back to the good ole elementary school days of needlessly shooting buffalo and overfishing because it was considered “educational.” This game is a zombie spoof of the ever so beloved pioneer traveling game. You get to name your crew, pick your items, and board up into your station wagon to hit up the west. There are mini-games of wrecking biking crews and shooting zombies. The shooting mechanics are a bit clunky, but when you practice you’ll get better at it. Use a mouse; using a Facebook’s machine’s mouse pad will leave your tired and frustrated. Cute music and sound effects, the pixelated graphics will grow on you. It’s a fun spin on the traditional game. It’s a good game to burn sometime on, and you’ll find yourself amused at your friends catching dysentery because we all know the only people who know of such a disorder are the people whose virtual bffs got it while playing the Oregon Trail.  So board up your “wagon” and get on your way. 8/10

For the price I paid for it, I'm not too upset about buying this game ... but, even at that price, this game is basically a one-shot joke that is given away in the title. If you're both a massive zombie fan and are nostalgic for the original Oregon Trail then maybe you would get slightly more enjoyment out of it, but I never played the Oregon Trail (although similar games from the same period, e.g. Granny's Garden if anyone remembers that...), and really there is only about 10-20 minutes of entertainment here.

On the plus side: the execution as far as they were aiming for is solid, the retro graphics style is done very well, and it's nice to hear a few bleeps and bloops. But the minigames get boring incredibly quickly, could've done with a few more of them to keep things varied, and there just isn't the depth to make this interesting to play. I got very close to winning on my first game but for the amount of content here it takes absolutely ages to get there and I wasn't compelled to try again.

However like I said, for a few quid you can't really go wrong, if you're intrigued by this game then you might as well go for it!

But the minigames get boring incredibly quickly, could've done with a few more of them to keep things varied, and there just isn't the depth to make this interesting to play. I got very close to winning on my first game but for the amount of content here it takes absolutely ages to get there and I wasn't compelled to try again.

However like I said, for a few quid you can't really go wrong, if you're intrigued by this game then you might as well go for it!

I had to look twice to see if this was a retro classic that had been re-released or ported to the steam store. But it turns out it's not, and is indeed an original/fresh game.

The graphics are authentic of what you would expect from a game during the days of the sega master system (and before). Do not be put down by the graphics however, as the gameplay is certainly there. I haven't had so much fun with a pixel based sprite game in at least a decade. There are lots of elements to the game that give you a rush of nostalgia, be it the music, the menu systems, or the animations, it certainly brought back memories of some titles on the sega mega drive; for me.

The various gameplay mechanics also work well, even though they are fairly simple. It's also quite fun to discover an old gravestone on the road-side (with a personal message that you wrote) on the next play through.

I also have to say that the soundtrack is brilliant. Most games that i enjoy for years to come have succeeded on the basis of the music and the gameplay alone, i think Organ Trail might be one of them.

I ended up with this game after the purchase of a recent humble-bundle, but having played a few hours through Organ Trail, i think it's somethin gi would've paid full price for on it's own.

10/10 from me. Lots of fun, and importantly; lots of replayability.

reviewText:
Organ Trail is an obvious parody of the old-school game 'Oregon Trail', a game I must admit I've never played, despite hearing so much about it.  I do know what makes a good game, though, and this is brilliant.

The aim of the game is simple; survive in a post-apocalyptic zombie-led world as you and four companions make it across the United States to the last remaining human stronghold.  Riding in a clapped-out station wagon, you'll need to gather what meagre supplies you can, keeping a close eye on your food, fuel, ammo and equipment for your vehicle, while riding from safe zone to safe zone.

At each safe zone, you'll be able to rest, repair and trade, along with taking part in optional scavenger missions or jobs that put you at greater risk.  The road between each zone is littered with random encounters, from conversation set pieces to shoot-outs, from graverobbing to surviving stampedes of undead animals.

What makes this game brilliant is it is the perfect balance of risk versus reward.  Low on food? You could scavenge the surroundings while multiple zombies approach, but if they catch you, it could be all for naught.  Can your station wagon survive until the next zone, or should you stop in no-mans land and attempt to repair it? How long should you keep a valuable companion alive that has been bitten by the undead?  Should you blast through that zombie horde, or wait for it to disperse while your supplies dwindle?  And should you push your vehicle faster, to save on food and get to Safe Haven? Or would you go at a more leisurely pace, and risk running low on supplies?

It's important to note that this game is a fun diversion, a full playthrough taking no more than a few hours.  The mini-games are varied but very basic, as are the graphics - don't get this expecting anything more than crudely drawn Amstrad style animations.  The companions that accompany you are also nothing more than the name you give them.  It's best, then, to go into this game with a wild imagination, rather than a massive expectation of an epic zombie survival thriller.

Finally, a shout-out must go to the gorgeous music, which is capable of inspiring terror and elation in equal measure.  It perfectly encapsulates the beautiful-yet-irrevocably scarred landscape that you must cross to reach your goal.

For the price, definitely recommended.

An excellent satire of the pioneering (pun intended) educational series, Oregon Trail.

Your car just keeps milling about on the road without any input from you.  Most of the time I just skip all the messages that pop up because it's all RNG.  You have no input in whether you lose a bunch of ammo or food.  The game just does everything for you while yoiu auto drive.

The different paths you take just means a faster route plus more hazards, like radiation sickness.  The towns are all the same. Some have trainers and others, upgrades for your car.  Thats really the only BIG difference in choosing a different path.

Scavenging gets old REAL fast.  If you buy the dlc, you can fight off humans as well as the undead.  All in all, it's a decent waste of time.  You just wont be coming back to it over and over.  It's more of a 1-2 hr time waster when you're really bored.

reviewText:
Dustforce truly is a work of art. I don't mean that lightly. The way it's animated plus its music gives it that title in my book. I can find myself playing one level for an hour, maybe even hours at a time. The frustration of losing levels is filled with relaxation and calmness because of the ambient music. The way the levels are crafted is truly mindblowing. They had a system in which you had to perfect a level to earn a key, and you would use that key to earn more levels. In layman's terms, to earn more levels, you had to perfect current levels. They ditched that and added an XP system in which you gain more XP to earn a key the more levels you play and perfect. I'm very glad they added this system and was skeptical about buying it. But now that I did buy it, I do not regret it even for a second. One thing I really love about this game is how you don't have to unlock base levels. In a sense, this game is open world. That sense is that many levels are available to you, and you can choose whether you want to advance into more challenging levels, or stay where you're at. To get an S in completion, you have to sweep up EVERY leaf, and to get an S in Finesse, you have to maintain your combo throughout an entire level.

Another thing I absolutely enjoy about Dustforce is its expasive community. There are lots of Community Workshop maps for you to sharpen your skills on, and lots of people who can set a good example. I'm sure most of the people who get best times on all the levels have a Youtube channel, so you can probably catch them there. The community may or not be active, but it sure is good and friendly.

Overall, in terms of gameplay, music, artstyle, animation, and difficulty (it's not an easy game, but it's not that hard of a game either. It just depends on how much you want to play it), I rate this game:

10/10

reviewText:
Zombies are IN for quite a while now and this game has been around for a few years as well. It was originally made as a parody of Oregon Trail, a really old game that had numerous re-releases (it was made in 1971 and had like 10 incarnations so far) that allowed a player to experience the settling in western United States. Organ Trail was a free flash/browser game that had a lot of fans, so the creators started a Kickstarter campaign to make a Director's Cut as a fully commercial title. After the funds were collected the game was made and is now available for Steam and mobile devices.

As the game starts you are given a station wagon with some limited supplies (food, scrap for car repairs, a few spare tires, mufflers, car batteries, medical kits...) and 4 companions. Your goal: reach safe haven at the west and survive the zombie apocalypse. The whole game is set around random events that occur as you travel from one city/settlement to another while scavenging supplies, trading with other people, fighting off zombie attacks, escaping gangs that are after your supplies etc. Each hour that passes (in a matter of 2 seconds) is a possible trigger for a random event and they vary from simple weather changes that can slow you down to encounters with all kinds of people (these trigger classic text adventure kind of stories).

Settlements offer a place to rest and trade and you can also get a job to earn some more supplies or money (arcade shootouts with zombies or bandits). Each city has a car shop that can upgrade your station wagon or a combat school to enhance your own abilities. Don't forget to refuel as well or you will get stranded in the middle of nowhere and forced to trade when you don't really want to.

The game looks and feels as if it was made in early 1980s and that gives it a specific charm. But don't let it turn you away! Seriously, it's kinda cute to have such a game in 2014 (or 2012, when it was made), a game that relies on gameplay rather than on awesome graphics. It's a lot of fun with all those events that may or may not occur, but it does have its limits. I completed it 4-5 times and it lost its charm - once you figure out the best way to gather supplies, when and where to sell them and what to buy instead - it gets real easy. True, there are difficulty levels but even the hardest one is hard only at the start. As for the zombie combat, I'll give you a tip: when you want to shoot a zombie click on the zombie and hold the mouse button as you drag it towards your avatar. It's a direct hit in 95% of cases.

I haven't played the mobile version (I got it as well, but I just never cared much for mobile games) so I can't say much about it. From what I saw online it's quite popular and people who own it love it! Give this game a chance, it's fun even though it's very limited.

reviewText: Organ Trail is retro zombie survival/strategy game. The art and music style are old school which I like. The aiming controls are kind of meh but you'll probably get used to them. I encountered a glitch on my second playthrough where the car just stopped. You couldn't stop to rest or fix the car, you couldn't enter land marks, you couldn't do anything. The only way to progress is to restart the game and when you get back in the car drives for a couple seconds and stops again. So you can keep restarting the game to progress but because you can't stop to heal or repair the car you will eventually die and there's nothing you can do to prevent it. So in the end I would say for the low price of $5 it's worth it. It may have bugs but it's still a really good game.

If you've played Oregon Trail, then you know what you're getting with the original Organ Trail; a pure parody of Oregon Trail set in a zombie infested post-apocalypic wasteland. Its gameplay is similar, its ideas are similar, and it's a lot of fun, just like the original source material.

Here's the thing though, Organ Trail: Director's Cut is everything the original Organ Trail is, and much much more. Rather than just a parody - and I agree fully with what the creators say they intended the game to be - it is a game that stands above and beyond its own source material as a game in its own right.

It's fun, it's dark, it's darkly funny, and it's honestly quite creepy in several places. The soundtrack is incredible and Ben Crossbones' musical talent lends itself perfectly, creating a wonderous, lonesome, tense and tragic air to the whole game. Rolling into a settlement (or the remains of a city), buying supplies and fixing/upgrading your Station Wagon, or learning new combat skills, trading and scavenging and talking with strangers was great before, but with the soundtrack it turns it into both wonderous relief and soul-crushing despair as you realise these are the few survivors left, and you should take what levity you can on your perilous road to a CHANCE at salvation.

Be warned however. Easy difficulty may not be as rewarding but it is fun. If you want the extra points bonuses, rack up the difficulty, but be prepared for ungodly amounts of pain, because the jump from Easy to Normal is IMMEDIATELY visible. You will suffer at the hands of the game for your greed, so be sure you're REALLY good at aiming for a start.

Total recommendation, totally worth every penny in sale or not. Get it, play it, love it. Just uh... don't play it late at night before you go to bed. You may have interesting dreams. o_o;

reviewText:
If you've played Oregon Trail, then you know what you're getting with the original Organ Trail; a pure parody of Oregon Trail set in a zombie infested post-apocalypic wasteland. Its gameplay is similar, its ideas are similar, and it's a lot of fun, just like the original source material.

Here's the thing though, Organ Trail: Director's Cut is everything the original Organ Trail is, and much much more. Rather than just a parody - and I agree fully with what the creators say they intended the game to be - it is a game that stands above and beyond its own source material as a game in its own right.

It's fun, it's dark, it's darkly funny, and it's honestly quite creepy in several places. The soundtrack is incredible and Ben Crossbones' musical talent lends itself perfectly, creating a wonderous, lonesome, tense and tragic air to the whole game. Rolling into a settlement (or the remains of a city), buying supplies and fixing/upgrading your Station Wagon, or learning new combat skills, trading and scavenging and talking with strangers was great before, but with the soundtrack it turns it into both wonderous relief and soul-crushing despair as you realise these are the few survivors left, and you should take what levity you can on your perilous road to a CHANCE at salvation.

Be warned however. Easy difficulty may not be as rewarding but it is fun. If you want the extra points bonuses, rack up the difficulty, but be prepared for ungodly amounts of pain, because the jump from Easy to Normal is IMMEDIATELY visible. You will suffer at the hands of the game for your greed, so be sure you're REALLY good at aiming for a start.

Total recommendation, totally worth every penny in sale or not. Get it, play it, love it. Just uh... don't play it late at night before you go to bed. You may have interesting dreams. o_o;

reviewText:
This is a pretty awesome game for those who have made memories with Oregon Trail, those who are looking for retro graphics, those who like zombies, and those who enjoy satire towards any of those things.

Pros
-Great Humor: (If you are a zombie fanatic, and have watched every zombie movie, played every zombie game, and read every zombie comic book, then you will pick up on all of the excellent humor sprinkled throughout this game. On top of that, there are a ton of nods to just older games in general, which is always awesome.)

-Retro Graphics: (A plus if you like them)

-Replayable: (If you only play through this once, you will only see about 10% of the humor, challenges, etc. Each playthrough yields different things, such as events, and you can take a different approach everytime. You can stock up on different items, strive to do different things, and changing your sense of morality at anytime. The only really linear thing in this game is the path. You go from Point A, then Point B, all the way to Point Z, which is the safe haven you are trying to get to. It is what happens on your way to each point that makes this game interesting.)

-Soundtrack: (This game has a really good sense of approach towards the situations you may be in, and one of the big reasons I say that is the soundtrack. The game always has fitting music, and good music at that.)

Cons

-Gameplay: (This is a subjective con. The gameplay is interesting in that it really is true to how an older game like this would play. But that doesn't mean it is easy. My only complaint on this is the aiming. Considering you must fight off the undead with a ranged weapon, you HAVE to be good at aiming it. On top of that, you can't waste ammo, as it could be out of reach due to price, or the shear lack of it in the zombie wastelands you explore. The aiming is...weird. I suggest looking up a video of gameplay so you can see if you can cope with it. I've gotten used to it, but at the same time I shouldn't have to. Gameplay should be fluid and creative, yet natural. Honestly, I would like just one of those, but aside from this one con, if you can overcome this one annoyance, then this game is definitely worth it.)

Verdict
Everything about this game is near-perfect, aside from one thing. Gameplay. While everything else is so good, this is a big thing to do deal with since without gameplay, it wouldn't be a game. At the same time, you have to see if it would bother you so I suggest looking at a video of the gameplay to decide. If, afterwards, you decide that isn't too bad, then nothing else should be stopping you from getting this game aside from lacking the funds to do so. Everything aligns almost perfectly for this game but one thing, so decide from all of this if you would truely like it.

P.S. There is also a mobile edition available for Android and iOS, so if you want to try this game but feel playing it with a mouse is a deal breaker, then that is the next best thing. The one thing both editions have over the free, Facebook alternative is that they are much more complete, and have A TON of addition content that adds to the experience of this game. The developer did fairly well on this title, so I trusted the mobile edition would live up to the PC edition here. Long story short, there is no game that really keeps itself consistent across all the platforms it's available on so well like this one!

reviewText:
Zombies are IN for quite a while now and this game has been around for a few years as well. It was originally made as a parody of Oregon Trail, a really old game that had numerous re-releases (it was made in 1971 and had like 10 incarnations so far) that allowed a player to experience the settling in western United States. Organ Trail was a free flash/browser game that had a lot of fans, so the creators started a Kickstarter campaign to make a Director's Cut as a fully commercial title. After the funds were collected the game was made and is now available for Steam and mobile devices.

As the game starts you are given a station wagon with some limited supplies (food, scrap for car repairs, a few spare tires, mufflers, car batteries, medical kits...) and 4 companions. Your goal: reach safe haven at the west and survive the zombie apocalypse. The whole game is set around random events that occur as you travel from one city/settlement to another while scavenging supplies, trading with other people, fighting off zombie attacks, escaping gangs that are after your supplies etc. Each hour that passes (in a matter of 2 seconds) is a possible trigger for a random event and they vary from simple weather changes that can slow you down to encounters with all kinds of people (these trigger classic text adventure kind of stories).

Settlements offer a place to rest and trade and you can also get a job to earn some more supplies or money (arcade shootouts with zombies or bandits). Each city has a car shop that can upgrade your station wagon or a combat school to enhance your own abilities. Don't forget to refuel as well or you will get stranded in the middle of nowhere and forced to trade when you don't really want to.

The game looks and feels as if it was made in early 1980s and that gives it a specific charm. But don't let it turn you away! Seriously, it's kinda cute to have such a game in 2014 (or 2012, when it was made), a game that relies on gameplay rather than on awesome graphics. It's a lot of fun with all those events that may or may not occur, but it does have its limits. I completed it 4-5 times and it lost its charm - once you figure out the best way to gather supplies, when and where to sell them and what to buy instead - it gets real easy. True, there are difficulty levels but even the hardest one is hard only at the start. As for the zombie combat, I'll give you a tip: when you want to shoot a zombie click on the zombie and hold the mouse button as you drag it towards your avatar. It's a direct hit in 95% of cases.

I haven't played the mobile version (I got it as well, but I just never cared much for mobile games) so I can't say much about it. From what I saw online it's quite popular and people who own it love it! Give this game a chance, it's fun even though it's very limited.

reviewText:
If you've played Oregon Trail, then you know what you're getting with the original Organ Trail; a pure parody of Oregon Trail set in a zombie infested post-apocalypic wasteland. Its gameplay is similar, its ideas are similar, and it's a lot of fun, just like the original source material.

Here's the thing though, Organ Trail: Director's Cut is everything the original Organ Trail is, and much much more. Rather than just a parody - and I agree fully with what the creators say they intended the game to be - it is a game that stands above and beyond its own source material as a game in its own right.

It's fun, it's dark, it's darkly funny, and it's honestly quite creepy in several places. The soundtrack is incredible and Ben Crossbones' musical talent lends itself perfectly, creating a wonderous, lonesome, tense and tragic air to the whole game. Rolling into a settlement (or the remains of a city), buying supplies and fixing/upgrading your Station Wagon, or learning new combat skills, trading and scavenging and talking with strangers was great before, but with the soundtrack it turns it into both wonderous relief and soul-crushing despair as you realise these are the few survivors left, and you should take what levity you can on your perilous road to a CHANCE at salvation.

Be warned however. Easy difficulty may not be as rewarding but it is fun. If you want the extra points bonuses, rack up the difficulty, but be prepared for ungodly amounts of pain, because the jump from Easy to Normal is IMMEDIATELY visible. You will suffer at the hands of the game for your greed, so be sure you're REALLY good at aiming for a start.

Total recommendation, totally worth every penny in sale or not. Get it, play it, love it. Just uh... don't play it late at night before you go to bed. You may have interesting dreams. o_o;

For those that never experienced old Apple 2 style games, most of this game's charm and humor will be lost on you.  But for those that sat in the computer lab, mindlessly clicking away, this game is a rare treat and a crystal ball looking back into your childhood.  Many take to adding in names of their friends, but for me, I always added Spiderman, Batman, etc.  And it's very telling when Bruce Wayne crumples up money and destroys it out of boredom.  Rich b***ard.  While some of the key controls, IE shooting are bass-akwards, it didn't stop me from enjoying other parts of the game.

While there is a working form of this game online, it doesn't have half the features of this game.  Do yourself a favor.  Get the full version and support the devs.  They gotta eat too.

Pros:
+Nostalgic look back at the old Oregon Trail game you played in school
+Interesting easter eggs located at nearly every checkpoint (From Final Fantasy, to Last of Us, to Shaun of the Dead, and more)
+Randomized events give high replay
+Interesting Achievements add another degree of difficulty (Can you make it without any money?  What about no trading? etc.)
+Good soundtrack mixed with old-school sound effects
+Endless mode makes it so you can unlock new starter modes!

Cons:
-God awful inverted gun controls with no settings to change to normal
-Glitchy counter, making certain achievements a course in futility
-Zombie 'Boss Fights' are more of an exercise in running away than fighting off the undead.
-Clements isn't around longer.

Read all this way?  You deserve a treat.  Don't bring your friends to a zom-pocolypse.  Bring Chuck Norris.  Seriously.  Bring him.
